div1.p: POLICE COURT
(Before H.C. Shaw, Esq., P.M.)
June 19th, 1915. Vancouver, B.C.
REX vs LEWIS JOHNSTON
POLICE COURT
(Before H.C. Shaw Esq., P.M.)
Vancouver, B.C. June 15th, 1915.
Canada Province of British Columbia County of Vancouver City of Vancouver
REX vs LEWIS JOHNSTON

LEWIS JOHNSTON charged on the infromation of E.E. Robinson of the city of Vancouver on the 15th day of June, 1915, for that at the said City of Vancouver on the 4th day of June, A.D. 1915, he did unlawfully steal the sum of $1800:00 the pro- perty of John Pritchard.
Contrary to the form of the Statute in such case made and provided.
J.K. KENNEDY, ESQ. Counsel for Prosecution
L.H. HEANEY, sworn as stenographer
JOHN PRITCHARD, Hotel Main. called as witness, as being first sworn, testified as follows:
QUESTIONS by MR KENNEDY:
1 Q. What is your occupation, Mr Pritchard? A. Wel I have not been doing anything for about three years. I ran a store at Ollala, in a mining camp at Ollala B.C. That was the last business I was in.
2 Q. When did you come to Vancouver last? A. I think about the 13th of February I came here. That would be about four months ago.

3 Q. Now on the 4th of June, Mr Pritchard, will you tell us in your own words what occurred in connection with this charge? A. Well I had a deal on for some land, and I went to the Bank and withdrew eighteen hundred dollars from the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Hastings Street; and my lawyer went over to West- minster to search the title for me that day, and I was waiting for him to come back, and he didn't get back till about 5:30

4 Q. We can shorten that a great deal. You had the eighteen hundred dollars in your pocket at what time of night? A. Well I had it when I was up
in the lawyer's office. That would be about six o'clock.

5 Q. Well what next? A. My lawyer and -r Shayer- that is the party I am buying the land from - we left the office and alked over to the Commercial Hotel and had a drink; and my lawyer, Mr. McGill he went away home, and we walked down as far as the Woods Hotel and got another drink; and that is the last I recollect.
6 Q. Who were with you when you had the drink at the Woods Hotel? A. Mr. Shayer
7 Q. And anybodyelse? A.No.
8 Q. And when you had a drink at the first Hotel? A. That was just after we left the office.
9 Q. Who was with you then? A. Mr. McGill, my lawyer, and Mr Shay er and myself.
10 Q. Are you a drinking man? A. Yes I have been drinking all my life, but not much.
11 Q. Have you ever had it happen recently that two drinks would put you clean out A. No
12 Q. What were you drinking? A. Seagrams Rye whiskey
13 Q. And that is the last you recollect till when? A. Till next morning at seven o'clock
14 Q. Where did you find yourself then? A. In the Hotel Main lying on the bed with my clothes on.
15 Q. Where is that with reference to the Woods Hotel? A. Why the Woods is on Hastings street and the Main is on. . . .
16 Q. How far away, how many blocks? A. About four blocks, five blocks, I guess
17 Q. Were you staying up at the Main Hotel at all? A. Yes I have been staying there all along since I have been in town.
18 Q. Did you find yourself in your own room then? A. Yes
19 Q. What about the money? A. When I woke up, the first thing I thought of was the money when I found what shape I was in lying on the bed, and I found it was gone.

20 Q. Were you dressed? A. I was lying on the bed with my
clothes on.
21 Q. When was the last time you that you remeber, that you saw you had the money? A. I don't know. I don't recollect any particular time that I had it.

22 Q. You say you had it when you were at the lawyer's office A. Yes and I am sure I had it when I was at the Woods. I am confident I had it at the Woods, although I don't recollect putting my hand on it.
23 Q. How were you carrying it? A. In a pocket-book in my left hand hip pocket?
24 Q. Had you shown the money to anybody at either of the Hotels that you recollect? A. No not at that time.
25 Q. Do you remember seeing at either Hotel any colored man A. No I don't

26 Q. What was the denominations of the money? A. There were seventeen hundred dollar bills and two fifties that I took out of the Bank, and then I'had some ten dollar bills in my pocket -- I think about ninety dollars in ten dollar bills in my pocket-book.
27 Q. In the same book? A.Yes in the same pocket-book, in the same pocket
28 Q. And the whole pocket-book was gone, A. Yes
29 Q. In all you lost how much? A. I think $180
30 Q. $180? A. $1880, I should say because I had change for a ten dollar bill in my pocket the next morning, and I think I must have changed a ten dollar bill some place. So I think I may say $1880.
31 Q. In the vicinity anyway? A. Yes
32 Q. I asked you a moment ago whether you are a drinking man; are you man who is in the habit of getting drunk? A. No not in the habit; once in a while I get off but I don't make a practice of it.
33 Q. Have you been on any spree recently> A. No.
34 Q. Had you gone out with the intention of a spree on this occasion at all? A. No certainly not.
35 Q. You say "certainly not" because you had so much money with you? A. Yes
